description: Ethnobotany and Indigenous stewardship for East Bay field trips — covers local plant identification, Ohlone plant uses, the concept of stewardship, and connecting past Indigenous land management to present-day responsibility. Designed for elementary school trail walks at Tilden Nature Area.

skills.label: Can identify oak (acorn), mugwort, soap root, and bay laurel by sight, smell, or touch
Knows the Ohlone peoples have lived in the East Bay for thousands of years and are still here today
Can name at least one way the Ohlone used each plant (food, medicine, cleaning, cooking)
Can explain that the Ohlone didn't just use plants — they cared for and managed them
Can describe stewardship as taking care of something so it's there for the future
Can give an example of Ohlone people or culture today (Sogorea Te' Land Trust, Ohlone Cafe, etc.)
Can describe one thing they can do to take care of nature for future people
